Who are some of your favorite women in #NY17 history?

Natalie Couch was a legal pioneer, and the first woman to vote in Rockland County. The Nyack native went on to break many barriers throughout her career as an attorney and activist. #InternationalWomensDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ev-NwV6WEAc3ZKW.jpg

Playwright Lorraine Hansberry lived much of her adult life in Croton-on-Hudson. Best known for her play A Raisin in the Sun, Hansberry used her art to advance racial and social justice. #InternationalWomensDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ev-Nrd4XMAIYw53.jpg

Sojourner Truth was an iconic abolitionist and activist who fought to include Black women in the fight for women‚Äôs equality. She lived and worked for years in Briarcliff. #InternationalWomensDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ev-Nkv_XYAI5ukn.jpg

Growing up, I wanted to be a writer because of the influence of Nobel and Pulitzer Prize-winning author Toni Morrison. The writer of iconic works like Songs of Solomon and Beloved, Morrison was a longtime resident of Nyack. #InternationalWomensDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ev-NZDgWYAIqVIr.jpg

Madam C.J. Walker revolutionized Black hair care and became the first self-made female millionaire in American history. She also called the Village of Irvington home for many years. #InternationalWomensDay http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Ev-OqvkWgAIbqZa.jpg

As we celebrate #InternationalWomensDay, I want to celebrate just a few of the countless women in history who have called #NY17 home.

This #InternationalWomensDay, let's take a moment to honor the immeasurable contributions made by women in every facet of our society. The pandemic has highlighted the countless roles women play in our world and the enormous price they pay to care for their families.
